Wenlan Zhang is a second-year PhD student at the The Bartlett Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis (CASA), University College London.


She is currently working on her research project titled ‚ÄúQuantifying Digital Injustice: The Utility of Digital Footprint Data in the Global South‚Äù, under the supervision of Dr.¬†Chen Zhong, Prof.¬†Mark Pelling, and Dr.¬†Faith Taylor.


Wenlan‚Äôs research interests lie in sustainable smart cities, particularly in Global South countries, and she aims to pursue a career in this sector in the future. Feel free to contact her to discuss potential projects.

title: Curriculum vitae
text: Download current CV

title: Projects
text:
Location: Euboea, Greece | Funded by: Interdisciplinary School for Environmental Crisis (ISEC)





üåç Open Data Fire Detection App  | üìä Project Presentation




Fire Monitoring: Led the fire monitoring efforts by developing and implementing a system to track and analyze wildfire activity using advanced spatial data analysis techniques.
Field Research: Conducted on-the-ground research to understand the causes of wildfires in Greece and their impact on local public health.
Environmental Monitoring: Developed tools for monitoring environmental changes, contributing to better disaster prevention and management strategies.
Policy Recommendations: Provided actionable policy recommendations for local authorities based on the findings from the fire monitoring and environmental analysis.





Fire Monitoring Application: Designed and launched a wildfire reporting system through a custom web application, showcasing my expertise in spatial data analysis.
Policy Recommendations: Provided actionable policy recommendations to local authorities, supporting disaster management and wildfire recovery efforts.

title: Projects
text:
Open Data Fire Detection App | Project Presentation
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Projects
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth‚Äôs history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

View the tutorial for this template (+ download link)

title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.

title: Education
text:
March 2022 - Present
Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis (CASA) | The Bartlett Faculty of the Built Environment | University College London
Research Topic:
Quantifying digital injustice: a case study of Nairobi, Kenya
Research Plan:
Developing a workflow to assess the performance of big data by comparing it with traditional methods in Nairobi, Kenya; identifying digitally invisible groups and proposing mitigation approaches to empower these groups for data-enabled decision-making.

title: Education
text:
March 2022 - Present
Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis (CASA) | The Bartlett Faculty of the Built Environment | University College London
Research Topic:
Quantifying digital injustice: a case study of Nairobi, Kenya
Research Plan:
Developing a workflow to assess the performance of big data by comparing it with traditional methods in Nairobi, Kenya; identifying digitally invisible groups and proposing mitigation approaches to empower these groups for data-enabled decision-making.

title: Education
section: MSc in Environmental Technology
text:
MSc in Environmental Technology
September 2019 - September 2020
Centre for Environmental Policy | Faculty of Natural Sciences | Imperial College London
Master Thesis:
Distributed Ledger Technology enabled passenger control system to maintain social distancing on public transport during COVID-19
Result & Outcome:
Applied a resource-sharing algorithm to the public transport sector to control passenger movement. The system, enhanced by distributed ledger technology, used smart card data from the London Underground to simulate and enforce compliance.

title: Education
section: BEng in Marine Resource Development Technology
text:
BEng in Marine Resource Development Technology
September 2015 - June 2019
Marine College | Shandong University

Bachelor Thesis:
An Anoxic Bio-Filter (ABF) - Membrane Bioreactor (MBR) combined process on high salinity wastewater treatment and the effect of membrane fouling
Result & Outcome:
Designed and installed an ABF system to enhance the existing MBR setup; conducted rigorous testing to evaluate the combined ABF-MBR process‚Äôs efficiency in denitrification and membrane fouling reduction; produced a comprehensive report detailing findings and recommendations.

title: Education
text:
March 2022 -
Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis (CASA) | The Bartlett Faculty of the Built Environment  | University College London
Research Topic: Comparing the utility of digital footprint data with existing methods on flood risk management and data injustice mitigation, a case study of Nairobi, Kenya
Research Plan: Developing a workflow to assess the performance of digital footprint data in flood risk management by comparing with traditional methods in Nairobi, Kenya; Identifying digital invisible groups and proposing mitigation approaches to empower these groups for data-enabled decision-making.

title: Projects
section: Land Cover Change Detection
text:
Land Cover Change Detection

Location: Peak District, UK | Funded by: The Alan Turing Institute





üìÑ Project Report | üíª Project Code


Project Responsibilities:

Algorithm Development: Led the creation of unsupervised AI/ML algorithms to detect land cover changes in the Peak District National Park using multispectral aerial photography.
Change Mapping: Produced detailed change maps, identifying areas of significant conservation interest, such as deforestation and peat restoration.
Environmental Monitoring: Contributed to improving tools for environmental monitoring, enabling better conservation efforts across the National Park.



Key Contributions:

Innovative Change Detection: Developed advanced algorithms using deep learning and other AI techniques to detect land cover changes with high accuracy.
Leadership and Facilitation: Served as one of the two facilitators of the team, demonstrating strong leadership and project management in a collaborative, time-sensitive environment.
Impactful Environmental Insights: Delivered crucial insights and tools for environmental monitoring, significantly advancing the understanding of land cover changes in the Peak District National Park.
